Explanation: Generic or brand drugs that are available at the lowest cost share for the plan
Generic or brand drugs that the plan offers at a higher cost to you than Tier 1 Preferred Generic drugs
This tier includes preferred brand-name drugs as well as some generic drugs.
Specialty drugs or high-cost non-preferred brands
Some injectables and other high-cost drugs

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.
Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

your covered insulin products, please refer to your Evidence of Coverage.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.
Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.
Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.
Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

This prescription drug has a Part B versus Part D administrative prior authorization requirement. This drug may be covered under Medicare Part B or D depending upon the circumstances. Information may need to be submitted describing the use and setting of the drug to make the determination.

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

 of using opioids. This limit helps minimize long-term opioid use. If you are new to the plan and have
 a recent history of using opioids, the pharmacy may override the limit when appropriate.

Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME).  of using opioids. This limit helps minimize long-term opioid use. If you are new to the plan and have

Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

An opioid drug used to treat pain may be limited to a 7-day supply if you don’t have a recent history
 of using opioids. This limit helps minimize long-term opioid use. If you are new to the plan and have
 a recent history of using opioids, the pharmacy may override the limit when appropriate.
Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.
Generic or brand drugs that are available at the lowest cost share for the plan
Generic or brand drugs that the plan offers at a higher cost to you than Tier 1 Preferred Generic drugs
This tier includes preferred brand-name drugs as well as some generic drugs.
Specialty drugs or high-cost non-preferred brands
Some injectables and other high-cost drugs

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

An opioid drug used to treat pain may be limited to a 7-day supply if you don’t have a recent history
 of using opioids. This limit helps minimize long-term opioid use. If you are new to the plan and have
 a recent history of using opioids, the pharmacy may override the limit when appropriate.
Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.

This prescription drug is not normally covered in a Medicare prescription drug plan. The amount you pay when you fill a prescription for this drug does not count towards your total drug costs (that is, the amount you pay does not help you qualify for catastrophic coverage). In addition, if you are receiving extra help to pay for your prescriptions, you will not get any extra help to pay for this drug.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

This vaccine is provided at no cost when used based on
recommendations by the Centers for Disease Control and
Prevention’s (CDC) Advisory Committee on Immunization

A generic medication is called by its chemical name; a manufacturer assigns a brand name. Both generic and brand name products have the same active ingredients. Generic medications are just as safe and effective as brand name medications. Preferred generic drugs are generally the most cost-effective and include most generic drugs.
These drugs may cost more than generics but less than non-preferred brands.

Non-preferred brand medications may have generic equivalents. Once a branded medication becomes available as a generic product, it moves to a non-preferred brand tier, and the generic becomes a non-preferred generic medication unless otherwise noted in the formulary. Non-preferred brand drugs are generally higher in cost than preferred brands.

Specialty medications are typically high-cost, self-administered (oral or injectable) drugs requiring significant support to manage and administer. These drugs often treat rare, chronic conditions and may require unique delivery or dispensing considerations. They usually involve additional patient support, safety monitoring, and compliance assistance.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

AGE (Age Requirement) refers to the minimum or maximum age limits set by insurance policies or healthcare plans that determine eligibility for coverage or specific benefits, ensuring treatment or coverage is appropriate for the patient’s age group.

This drug
 may be eligible for payment under Medicare Part B or Part D. You (or your physician) are

EXPANSION: Prior Authorization Restriction for New Starts Only
Explanation: Prior authorization applies only for new users or members; it does not apply for those already receiving the drug.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Limited Distribution Drug (LDD) refers to a medication that is dispensed through a restricted network of pharmacies, often because it is used to treat complex, rare, or specialty medical conditions. These drugs are usually managed by the pharmaceutical manufacturers who limit distribution to specific, highly trained pharmacies to ensure proper handling, storage, administration, and monitoring.

The Low-Cost Generic [LCG] tier offers copays lower than the cost-share for the generic tier, when possible. This applies to certain generic drugs that are typically used to treat chronic conditions such as high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, heart failure, and depression. Benefits may vary. Not all plans provide this incentive. The drug list is subject to change. When this incentive is not available on a plan, these drugs will be covered at the generic cost-share level.

Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

EXPANSION: Prior Authorization Restriction for Part B vs Part D Determination
Explanation: Authorized Generics [AG] are brand-name drugs that are marketed without the brand name on its label. An authorized generic may be marketed by the brand-name drug company, or another company with the brand company’s permission. These drugs are approved by the FDA. But they are not approved through the abbreviated new drug application (ANDA) process like a standard generic drug. For cost sharing purposes, authorized generics are treated as brand-name drugs and are not eligible for coverage on the generic tier(s)

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.

Additional quantity limits may apply to all opioid drugs used to treat pain. This additional limit is called a cumulative morphine milligram equivalent (MME). It’s designed to monitor safe dosing levels of opioids for people who may be taking more than 1 opioid drug for pain management. If your doctor or prescriber prescribes more than this amount or thinks the limit is not right for your situation, you or your doctor or prescriber can ask the plan to cover the additional quantity.

Prior authorization required only if starting the medication as a new user/new start. Continuing users may not require reauthorization.

This prescription drug has a Part B versus Part D administrative prior authorization requirement. This drug may be covered under Medicare Part B or D depending upon the circumstances. Information may need to be submitted describing the use and setting of the drug to make the determination.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.
Specialty drugs are used to treat difficult, long-term conditions. You may need to get this drug through a specialty pharmacy.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Under this health care reform law, if you qualify, you can get your drug at no cost if it is right for your age and condition and used properly.

HDHP (High Deductible Health Plan) formulary exception allows coverage for medically necessary drugs outside the standard formulary, ensuring access to essential medications despite higher deductibles and plan cost-sharing limits.

HSA (Health Savings Account) formulary exception allows coverage for non-formulary medications when medically necessary, ensuring access to essential treatments beyond standard covered drugs in the comprehensive drug list.
Specialty drugs are used to treat difficult, long-term conditions. You may need to get this drug through a specialty pharmacy.
P&T committees are responsible for assessing clinical evidence, safety data, and cost considerations to select the safest, most effective, and most economical medications for patient care.
New Drug Application (NDA) is a formal request to the FDA for approval to market a new drug in the United States, providing detailed data on its safety, effectiveness, and manufacturing.​
An Abbreviated New Drug Application (ANDA) is a regulatory submission to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for the approval of a generic drug.
The BLA is required for any company seeking to market a biologic—such as vaccines, blood products, monoclonal antibodies, gene therapies, and cellular therapies—in the US

These are medications included on the plan's Preferred Drug List (PDL) or formulary because they offer the best therapeutic value for the lowest net cost, based on clinical evidence and negotiations with pharmaceutical manufacturers.
Refers to brand-name drugs on a formulary that are not in the preferred tier, usually resulting in higher copayments or coinsurance compared to preferred brand-name drugs.
Minimum and maximum age requirements set by an insurance policy or plan that determine when an individual can apply for coverage or renew a policy, often used to manage risk and eligibility.

Approved brand medication marketed by either the brand company or another company without the brand name on its label. Authorized brand alternatives are drugs that are considered brand-name drugs and don’t have generic equivalents. These drugs are the same as the brand- name drugs but are not true generic drugs. The respective brand out-of-pocket costs will apply for these medications. Some authorized brand alternatives may not be covered.

Quantity level limits help encourage medication use as intended by the FDA. Quantity level limits are placed on medications in certain drug categories. For the medications listed in this document, if a quantity level limit applies, it will generally be noted next to the medication with a dot under the quantity level limits column. Limits may include quantity of covered medication per prescription, quantity of covered medication in a given time period, coverage only for members within a certain age range, and coverage only for members of a specific gender. If your doctor prescribes a greater quantity of medication than what the quantity level limit allows, you can still get the medication

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.
Dispensing limits apply to this drug. This drug is limited to a 1-month supply per prescription.

HDHP (High Deductible Health Plan) formulary exception allows coverage for medically necessary drugs outside the standard formulary, ensuring access to essential medications despite higher deductibles and plan cost-sharing limits.

HSA (Health Savings Account) formulary exception allows coverage for non-formulary medications when medically necessary, ensuring access to essential treatments beyond standard covered drugs in the comprehensive drug list.

AGE (Age Requirement) refers to the minimum or maximum age limits set by insurance policies or healthcare plans that determine eligibility for coverage or specific benefits, ensuring treatment or coverage is appropriate for the patient’s age group.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

EXPANSION: Quantity Limits is applied after Prior Authorization approval
Explanation: After a drug receives PA approval, the pharmacy system will also enforce QL based on plan policy. This means that even if your doctor gets approval for you to use the medicine, you cannot exceed the set amount (e.g., only 30 tablets per 30 days) unless the plan also approves a QL exception or override

EXPANSION: Prior Authorization Medications – Part B or D
Explanation: Drugs that may be covered under Medicare Part B or Part D depending on the circumstance. These drugs require prior authorization to determine coverage under Part B or Part D. Information may need to be provided that describes the use or the place where the drug is received to determine coverage.

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.
This vaccine is provided at no cost when used based on recommendations by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s (CDC) Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP).

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.
These drugs are available only through certain pharmacies or wholesalers, depending on what the manufacturer decides.

Our plan requires you or your prescriber to get prior authorization for certain drugs. This means that you will need to get approval from us before you fill your prescriptions. If you don’t get approval, we may not cover the drug.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.
These drugs are available only through certain pharmacies or wholesalers, depending on what the manufacturer decides.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *

This prescription drug has a Part B versus Part D administrative prior authorization requirement. This drug may be covered under Medicare Part B or D depending upon the circumstances. Information may need to be submitted describing the use and setting of the drug to make the determination.

These drugs are for complex medical conditions and may require special handling and/or close monitoring. They are available through CVS Specialty Pharmacy Services and may be available at other specialty pharmacies in the network

According to medical experts, these drugs may cause adverse side effects if you are 65 years of age or older. If you are taking one of these drugs, ask your doctor if there are safer options available.

For certain drugs, our plan limits the amount of the drug that we will cover. For example, our plan provides 30 tablets per 30 days per prescription for atorvastatin. This may be in addition to a standard one‑month or three‑month supply.

In some cases, our plan requires you to first try certain drugs to treat your medical condition before we will cover another drug for that condition. For example, if Drug A and Drug B both treat your medical condition, we may not cover Drug B unless you try Drug A first. If Drug A does not work for you, we will then cover Drug B.
These drugs are available only through certain pharmacies or wholesalers, depending on what the manufacturer decides.

For certain kinds of drugs, you can use CVS Caremark® Mail Service Pharmacy. Generally, the drugs available through mail order are drugs that you take on a regular basis, for a chronic or long‑term medical condition. The drugs available through our plan’s mail‑order service are marked as “MO” in our Drug List. *

This prescription drug has a Part B versus Part D administrative prior authorization requirement. This drug may be covered under Medicare Part B or D depending upon the circumstances. Information may need to be submitted describing the use and setting of the drug to make the determination.

According to medical experts, these drugs may cause adverse side effects if you are 65 years of age or older. If you are taking one of these drugs, ask your doctor if there are safer options available.

Available to some members at no cost with a prescription from your provider when obtained at an in-network pharmacy. Certain limitations may apply.
Non-preferred generic and non-preferred brand Drug name drugs

Refers to specialty drugs that are high-cost, complex medications placed in a non-preferred tier on insurance formularies, leading to higher patient cost-sharing and often requiring special handling and prior authorization.
Brand-name drugs on an insurance formulary that are favored due to negotiated discounts or rebates, resulting in lower copayments or coinsurance compared to non-preferred brand drugs.
Generic drugs that are favored on an insurance formulary due to their lower cost and availability, resulting in the lowest copayments for patients compared to brand-name or non-preferred drugs.

Refers to specialty brand-name drugs that are preferred on an insurance formulary for their cost-effectiveness compared to alternatives, resulting in lower patient costs than non-preferred specialty drugs while still addressing serious or rare conditions requiring special handling.
Minimum and maximum age requirements set by an insurance policy or plan that determine when an individual can apply for coverage or renew a policy, often used to manage risk and eligibility.

Insurance coverage for a drug or treatment is determined based on the specific medical condition or indication for which the drug is prescribed, often requiring that the drug be used only for FDA-approved or medically supported indications to qualify for coverage.

when a generic version of a drug is available, the patient pays the lowest copayment amount applicable to the generic drug tier, ensuring the lowest out-of-pocket cost compared to brand-name alternatives.

EXPANSION: Drug tier when CE doesnot apply
Explanation: Drug tier when CE does not apply means the drug is assigned to a specific coverage tier in the formulary where clinical effectiveness (CE) criteria or certain utilization management rules do not influence the tier placement or coverage decision, often resulting in standard tier-based cost sharing without exceptions based on clinical criteria.
Only available for select plans. Refer to member plan documents for coverage.

EXPANSION: (Quantiy Limit) QL Restriction based on Age
Explanation: Quantity Limit Restriction Based on Age means that the insurance plan imposes limits on the amount or quantity of a drug that can be dispensed, with these limits varying depending on the patient’s age to ensure safe and appropriate usage.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.
This prescription cannot be filled for more than a 30-day supply.

Drugs are considered “limited access” if the FDA says the drug can only be given out by certain facilities, doctors or prescribers. These drugs may require extra handling, provider coordination or patient education that can’t be done at a network pharmacy.

Refers to specialty drugs that are high-cost, complex medications placed in a non-preferred tier on insurance formularies, leading to higher patient cost-sharing and often requiring special handling and prior authorization.
Brand-name drugs on an insurance formulary that are favored due to negotiated discounts or rebates, resulting in lower copayments or coinsurance compared to non-preferred brand drugs.
Generic drugs that are favored on an insurance formulary due to their lower cost and availability, resulting in the lowest copayments for patients compared to brand-name or non-preferred drugs.

Refers to specialty brand-name drugs that are preferred on an insurance formulary for their cost-effectiveness compared to alternatives, resulting in lower patient costs than non-preferred specialty drugs while still addressing serious or rare conditions requiring special handling.
Minimum and maximum age requirements set by an insurance policy or plan that determine when an individual can apply for coverage or renew a policy, often used to manage risk and eligibility.

Insurance coverage for a drug or treatment is determined based on the specific medical condition or indication for which the drug is prescribed, often requiring that the drug be used only for FDA-approved or medically supported indications to qualify for coverage.

when a generic version of a drug is available, the patient pays the lowest copayment amount applicable to the generic drug tier, ensuring the lowest out-of-pocket cost compared to brand-name alternatives.

EXPANSION: Drug tier when CE doesnot apply
Explanation: Drug tier when CE does not apply means the drug is assigned to a specific coverage tier in the formulary where clinical effectiveness (CE) criteria or certain utilization management rules do not influence the tier placement or coverage decision, often resulting in standard tier-based cost sharing without exceptions based on clinical criteria.

BvsD (Part B vs Part D) refers to the distinction between Medicare Part B and Part D drug coverage: Part B covers certain medications typically administered in medical settings (like injections, infusions, or durable medical equipment) such as immunosuppressants and some cancer drugs, while Part D covers most outpatient prescription drugs taken at home, including chronic condition medications.
